original: Saṁyutta Nikāya 30.1🔽1. Supaṇṇavagga🔽Suddhikasutta🔽Sāvatthinidānaṁ.🔽“Catasso imā, bhikkhave, supaṇṇayoniyo.🔽Katamā catasso?🔽Aṇḍajā supaṇṇā, jalābujā supaṇṇā, saṁsedajā supaṇṇā, opapātikā supaṇṇā—🔽imā kho, bhikkhave, catasso supaṇṇayoniyo”ti.🔽Paṭhamaṁ.🔽Saṁyutta Nikāya 30.2🔽1. Supaṇṇavagga🔽Harantisutta🔽Sāvatthinidānaṁ.🔽“Catasso imā, bhikkhave, supaṇṇayoniyo.🔽Katamā catasso?🔽Aṇḍajā …pe…🔽imā kho, bhikkhave, catasso supaṇṇayoniyo.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, aṇḍajā supaṇṇā aṇḍajeva nāge haranti, na jalābuje, na saṁsedaje, na opapātike.
analyzed: sayutta nikāya  supaṇṇa vagga  suddhika sutta  sāvatthi nidāna  catasso imāḥ bhikkhave supaṇṇa yoniyaḥ  katamā  aṇḍa jā su paṇṇā jalābu jā su paṇṇā sa seda jā su paṇṇā opapātikā su paṇṇā  imāḥ kho bhikkhave catasso supaṇṇa yoniyaḥ ti  paṭhama  sayutta nikāya  supaṇṇa vagga  harantisutta  sāvatthi nidāna  catasso imāḥ bhikkhave supaṇṇa yoniyaḥ  katamā  aṇḍa jā pe  imāḥ kho bhikkhave catasso supaṇṇa yoniyaḥ  tatra bhikkhave aṇḍa jā su paṇṇā aṇḍa ja iva nāge haranti na jalābu je na sa seda je na opapātike
translated: Linked Discourses With Sāriputta 30🔽1. The Group on Supaṇṇas🔽With Suddhāka🔽At Sāvatthī.🔽“Monks, there are these four kinds of birth for supaṇṇas.🔽What four?🔽Supaṇṇas born from an egg, born from the womb, born from moisture, and supernaturally born.🔽These are the four kinds of birth for supaṇṇas.”🔽The first section for recitation on the supaṇṇas is finished.🔽Linked Discourses With Sāriputta 30🔽1. The Group on Supaṇṇas🔽Carry Off🔽At Sāvatthī.🔽“Monks, there are these four kinds of birth for supaṇṇas.🔽What four?🔽Supaṇṇas born from an egg …🔽These are the four kinds of birth for supaṇṇas.🔽Therein, monks, supaṇṇas born from an egg carry off only those nāgas born from an egg, not those born from the womb, not those born from moisture, and not those supernaturally born.🔽

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, saṁsedajā supaṇṇā aṇḍaje ca jalābuje ca saṁsedaje ca nāge haranti, na opapātike.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave sa seda jā supaṇṇā aṇḍa je ca jalābu je ca sa seda je ca nāge haranti na opapātike
translated: The garuḍas born from eggs, from an embryo, or from moisture can carry nāgas born from eggs, from an embryo, or from moisture, but not those that are spontaneously born.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, opapātikā supaṇṇā aṇḍaje ca jalābuje ca saṁsedaje ca opapātike ca nāge haranti.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave opapātikā supaṇṇā aṇḍa je ca jalābu je ca saseda je ca opapātike ca nāge haranti
translated: The garuḍas that are spontaneously born can carry nāgas born from eggs, from an embryo, from moisture, or that are spontaneously born.

analyzed: imāḥ kho bhikkhave catasso supaṇṇa yoniyaḥ ti
translated: These are the four kinds of garuḍas.”
The second🔽Saṃyutta Nikāya
The Book of the Birds
The One Who Does Two Things
At Sāvatthī.

original: Aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: aññataraḥ bhikkhu yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho saḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: A certain monk went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

original: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjatī”ti?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho bhante hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena midhekaccaḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā aṇḍa jānam su paṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati iti
translated: “What is the cause, Venerable Sir, what is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the egg-born birds?”

original: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena dvayakārī hoti, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ekaccaḥ kāyena dvaya kārī hoti vācāya dvaya kārī manasā dvaya kārī
translated: “Here, monk, someone does two things with their body, two things with their speech, and two things with their mind.
He hears this:🔽

analyzed: aṇḍa jā su paṇṇāḥ dīgha āyukāḥ vaṇṇavantaḥ sukha bahulāḥ ati
translated: He hears that the golden-clad divine birds have a long life, are beautiful, and enjoy great happiness.
He thinks:

original: ‘aho vatāhaṁ kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjeyyan’ti.
analyzed: aho vata aham kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā aṇḍa jānam su paṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjeyyanti
translated: ‘Oh, when my body breaks up and my life ends, may I be reborn with the golden-clad divine birds.’

original: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā aṇḍa jānam su paṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati
translated: When his body breaks up, after death, he is reborn with the golden-clad divine birds.

original: Ayaṁ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṁ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjatī”ti.
analyzed: ayam kho bhikkhu hetu ayam paccayaḥ yena midhā ekaccaḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā aṇḍa jānam su paṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati iti
translated: This is the reason, this is the cause, why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn with the golden-clad divine birds.”
The third.🔽The Connected Discourses with Devadatta, the third section.
The Book of the Fives
The Second, Third, and Fourth on the One Who Does Two Things, etc.
At Sāvatthī.

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho saḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: As he was sitting there, he said to the Blessed One,

original: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā jalābujānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ …pe…
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho bhante hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena midhekaccaḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā jalābu jānam su paṇṇānam pe
translated: “What, lord, is the reason, what is the cause why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in companionship with the golden-clad divine birds?🔽… the egg-born divine birds?
… the moisture-born divine birds?
to be reborn in the company of the hell-warped birds?”

original: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena dvayakārī hoti, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ekaccaḥ kāyena dvaya kārī hoti vācāya dvaya kārī manasā dvaya kārī
translated: “Here, bhikkhu, someone acts in two ways by way of the body, speech, and mind.
He has heard:

analyzed: opapātikā su paṇṇāḥ dīgha āyukāḥ vaṇṇavantaḥ sukha bahulāḥ ati
translated: ‘The hell-warped birds have a long life span, are beautiful, and are endowed with happiness.’
He thinks:

original: ‘aho vatāhaṁ kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā opapātikānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjeyyan’ti.
analyzed: aho vata aham kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā opapātikānam supaṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjeyyanti
translated: ‘Oh, with the breakup of the body, after death, may I be reborn in companionship with the hell-warped birds!’

original: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā opapātikānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā opapātikānam supaṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati
translated: With the breakup of the body, after death, he is reborn in companionship with the hell-warped birds.

original: Ayaṁ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṁ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā opapātikānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjatī”ti.
analyzed: ayam kho bhikkhu hetu ayam paccayaḥ yena midhā ekaccaḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā opapātikānam supaṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati iti
translated: This is the cause and reason why someone, with the breakup of the body, after death, is reborn in companionship with the hell-warped birds.”
The sixth.
Saṁyutta Nikāya 3.10🔽The Garuḍa Group

analyzed: aṇḍa ja da anūpa kāra sutta dasaka
translated: Ten Suttas on the Benefits of Giving Eggs
At Sāvatthī.

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho saḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: As he was sitting there, he said to the Blessed One:

original: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjatī”ti?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho bhante hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena midhekaccaḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā aṇḍa jānam su paṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati iti
translated: “What is the cause, what is the reason why someone, at the break-up of the body, after death, re-appears in the company of the egg-born birds?”

original: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena dvayakārī hoti, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ekaccaḥ kāyena dvaya kārī hoti vācāya dvaya kārī manasā dvaya kārī
translated: “Here, monk, someone is double-tongued, backbiting, a tale-bearer, not well-spoken, not a listener, not a doer of what he has heard, not a giver, not a speaker of what he has heard.
He has heard this:

analyzed: aṇḍa jā su paṇṇāḥ dīgha āyukāḥ vaṇṇavantaḥ sukha bahulāḥ ati
translated: ‘The egg-born birds have long lives, beauty, pleasure, and are very happy.’
He thinks:

original: ‘aho vatāhaṁ kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjeyyan’ti.🔽So annaṁ deti …pe…
analyzed: aho vata aham kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā aṇḍa jānam su paṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjeyyanti  saḥ annam deti pe
translated: ‘Oh, may I, at the break-up of the body, after death, reappear in the company of the egg-born birds!’🔽He gives food …

analyzed: pānam deti  vattham deti  yānam deti
translated: He gives drink …🔽He gives clothes …🔽He gives a vehicle …
He gives a garland …🔽He gives scent …
He gives ointment …🔽He gives a bed …
He gives a dwelling …
He gives a lamp.

original: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā aṇḍa jānam su paṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati
translated: At the break-up of the body, after death, he re-appears in the company of the egg-born birds.

original: Ayaṁ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṁ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjatī”ti.
analyzed: ayam kho bhikkhu hetu ayam paccayaḥ yena midhā ekaccaḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā aṇḍa jānam su paṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati iti
translated: This is the reason, this is the cause, why someone, with the breakup of the body, after death, is reborn in companionship with the egg-born birds.”
The sixteenth.
Saṃyutta Nikāya 4.17
The Supaṇṇa Group
The Benefits of Giving a Pond
At Sāvatthī.

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho saḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: As he was sitting there, he said to the Blessed One,

original: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā jalābujānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ …pe…
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho bhante hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena midhekaccaḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā jalābu jānam su paṇṇānam pe
translated: “What, lord, is the reason, what is the condition, why someone, with the breakup of the body, after death, is reborn in companionship with the womb-born birds? …
with the moisture-born birds? …
with the spontaneously-born birds?”

original: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena dvayakārī hoti, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ekaccaḥ kāyena dvaya kārī hoti vācāya dvaya kārī manasā dvaya kārī
translated: “There is the case where someone is double-tongued, a user of subterfuges, deceitful, tricky, not a bearer of his word, faithless, rude, unmindful, unconcentrated, and of loose mindfulness.
He has heard:

analyzed: opapātikā su paṇṇāḥ dīgha āyukāḥ vaṇṇavantaḥ sukha bahulāḥ ati
translated: ‘The spontaneously-born birds are long-lived, beautiful, & replete with pleasure.’
The thought occurs to him, ‘O that—with the breakup of the body, after death—I may be reborn in companionship with the spontaneously-born birds!’

original: ‘aho vatāhaṁ kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā opapātikānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjeyyan’ti.🔽So annaṁ deti …pe…
analyzed: aho vata aham kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā opapātikānam supaṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjeyyanti  saḥ annam deti pe
translated: ‘May I, with the breakup of the body, after death, be reborn together with the spontaneously born devas of the Supaṇṇa realm.’🔽He gives food …
He gives drink …
He gives lamps.

original: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā opapātikānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā opapātikānam supaṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati
translated: With the breakup of the body, after death, he is reborn together with the spontaneously born devas of the Supaṇṇa realm.

original: Ayaṁ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṁ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā opapātikānaṁ supaṇṇānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjatī”ti.
analyzed: ayam kho bhikkhu hetu ayam paccayaḥ yena midhā ekaccaḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā opapātikānam supaṇṇānam sahabyatam upapajjati iti
translated: This is the cause, this is the reason, why someone, with the breakup of the body, after death, is reborn together with the spontaneously born devas of the Supaṇṇa realm.”
The forty-sixth.

analyzed: evam piṇḍakena chacattālīsam suttantāḥ honti  supaṇṇa vaggaḥ paṭhamaḥ
translated: (In this way, with the alms round, there are forty-six suttas.)
The first sub-chapter on Supaṇṇa is finished.🔽The summary:
They carry off pure,
and the four who do two things,
the thirty on giving help,🔽are well-explained in the Supaṇṇa section.
The Supaṇṇa Saṃyutta is finished.
